reviews.text: a very impressive structure, even more so when you take into account the history of it's construction and hundreds of years of operation. To think that another layer of civilization lies just beneath it's stones is humbling.  The entire area is very scenic, bustling, and photogenic.

in the cathedral until.certain part you can act as a tourist and take pictures and walk on by...but there is a sector in which you have to hear the mass and enjoy the religious spirit of that place like any other conventional church in the world..good memories from 2014
The cathedral is absolutely breathtaking. It is an active place of worship, so be mindful of those praying. But take lots of pictures.

Metropolitan cathedral is right at zocalo. The church was quite nice and the accoustics were very interesting. The prayers seem to boom in the church creating a very calm atmosphere. It is a quick visit and is open past 5 which means you can visit the cathedral after all the other things close down.

The cathedral is stunning and worth the visit. And can get really crowded between all the tourists escaping the sun and the actual services that are constantly taking place. Be sure to note how the building is leaning due to the fact it’s built on top of a pyramid.

The Virgin of Guadalupe is the Lady of Mexico and Mexicans are very much devoted to her. In every house, you find a little representation of the virgin. 

It is a very old church and they have maintain it properly. The monument itself is very beautiful. Because of how crowded it gets, they put an electric corridor so that people move/flow. 

In the back part of the church you will find a store with all kinds of religious gifts.

This Basilica is new compared to the temple next door, and they do have service plenty of times.  The place is big and it was finished being built in the 70's and it remains to look this way.  The place offers plenty of space to sit and stand. They have chapels in the second floor and plenty of doors to open the outdoors in.  
Here you can also visit the original image of the Virgin of Guadalupe.  
Pilgrimages are made to end at the basilica so if you visit, see the calendar of events so you may visit then or another time so you can avoid the large crowds.  Thousands of people visit this place.

The tilma (cloak) of St. Juan Diego is a scientific, historical and artistic marvel as well as a religious treasure. It will leave a deep and lasting impression on all who visit this basilica. Whether you are Catholic, Protestant, or come from another faith tradition, as you learn more about this artifact you will come to understand why 20 million people every year visit this place. And the faith of the people of Mexico will not fail to touch you as well. Very inspiring and uplifting.

What an interesting and historical site. Beautiful architecture of multiple periods, all decorated with the throngs of worshipers and activity.  If these walls could talk, what would they say?  I was surprised at the architecture of the old basilica, it seems to me sinking or isn't even when you walk through its interior.  I would say this was a highlight of our trip.

It's a local landmark and a must see if you're into religion or into history. The main church has masses all day and you can preview the Guadalupe Frame. Its a cool place to check out. You can be in and out within an hour. The coolest part is the climb in the nearby hill to view a part of the city.

Had an amazing time here. All the music coming from different places was interesting. The mariachis were great and their music is unforgettable. Once in the plaza Garibaldi you will have many options to go an eat and/or drink. I went to the oldest place open and it was the most amazing meal and experience ever.

During the day it looks nice and there are plenty of restaurants to eat either inside or outside.  But at night there are plenty of mariachis playing and you can hire one for any occasion.  You can walk around and listen to a small group of mariachis or a large group. It is one of the places to come and visit when in Mexico City.  Just do not walk very late at night towards the city.  Walk towards the main avenue and take your transportation to where you are staying. If you go away from the main avenue it is not the best neighborhood at night.

Lots of music around. Great atmosphere. The only down side is that you cannot enjoy the music at times unless they are playing for you since there is more than one song being played at the same time. Drink outside..pay off the cops. Look for my homie with the cane.

Always fun to listen to the mariachi and the evening we passed thru they were playing Coco on a big screen. It's a free experience and you can just sit and watch the bands play and the people pass by. You are welcome to bring your own alcoholic beverages from the look of it to enjoy with the bands playing.

While this plaza was traditional and romantic many years ago, it now sits in the middle of a not very nice part of town.  Every known and unknown mariachi band is in the plaza to play a song or symphony for you.  They charge, of course.  Enjoy it if you like crass commercialization at its finest.  May the spirit of the dead know mariachi keep the modern mariachis inspired to spread good music and fine morals.

An amazing and beautiful market of local crafts and goods. A must visit if you want hand made gifts such as poterry or decorations for your home. 

You can find all sorts of things here from jewelry, magnets, hand painted pottery, wall hangings, decorative fabrics, to clothes.

I felt very safe walking around alone as a woman not knowing any Spanish. Most people don't know English but I was able to get by fine. Some places take cards but I recommend having cash on you. 

Don't skip this place!

Our favorite market in Mexico City (so far), with lots of options, a cafe, and plenty to do in the surrounding area. The library and park to the south make this market worth the trip from across the city. 
Standard tourist craft market but relaxing and plenty of options. 
I just wish that one lady would’ve bargained more for those pillow cases...

Very nice craft market. Highly recommended to go here even if you aren't buying anything. Come here for sure if you are looking to buy some souvenirs to bring back home. They have a huge selection of hand crafts. Also they speak enough English there and they do not try to pressure you into buying things. Everyone at the market was very pleasant and fun to speak with. You can get by with limited spanish as well. The prices are reasonable as well.

We visited this market on a Monday morning and it was not crowded at all. Most of the vendors are very friendly and they don't pressure you to buy at all which is great! They can also speak sufficient English for a transaction. Helps to know a bit of Spanish for the numbers but that's not necessary. Would recommend this for souvenirs (ceramics, wooden Mexican crafts and textiles. Also - little colourful Jenga!)
Great place to see where locals buy goods and other things. Lots of fresh meat for sale. Also fried Scorpion 🤯 crocodile tacos and much more

Great place to hang out and the best movies too, the prices are extremely cheap there's always a good amount of people so I'll recommend to get there with a half hour or 45 minutes of anticipation. It's a nice movie theater, different and unique !!

Great place to enjoy art films. All the building is really nice, there are gardens and public spaces such as a bookstore, gift shops, a cafeteria, small restaurants and of course a place to buy popcorn and snacks for the film.

The best Latin American film archive I've ever visited. It's easy to access and it's slick. It has an incredibly well designed viewing room with a well designed user friendly interface and properly calibrated monitors. Make sure you bring a sweater it gets cold inside and a 5 peso coin for the lockers.

One of my favorite things in Mexico city. There are always good movies on display. Tickets are cheap. The ambience is good. Even if you just wanna go to hang out it's a cool place. It constantly has all sorts of festivals and special screenings. If you live in Mexico city... do go!
I love Cineteca Nacional! A great place to watch movies and drink coffee or simply read on green areas while enjoying the environment!
Bello lugar para visitar, descansar, apreciar, ir a leer
Un cementerio bastante cuidado, es extraño encontar un lugar de estos pegados al desmadre de circuito y San cosme.

Such an amazing experience! The zoo is giant and is free to everyone, it has so many animals!! There's many people selling food, toys, and souvenirs in the park! If you're visiting Mexico City I highly recommend coming to Chapultepec park and zoo, if you can I would recommend coming between Mon-Fri because it gets packed on the weekend...

This park is 100% FREEEEEEEE! YOU DONT NEED TO PAY ANYTHING TO GET IN. This place is very large with lots of things to do. You can go check out the animal exhibit that is completely free however backpacks and food is not allowed inside the animal park. There is also a castle you can check out very famous with lots of history and a lake with little pedal boats you can rent for cheap. Come see this beautiful place that is family friendly and has lots of things to do and see and of course, EAT.

GREAT VISIBILITY of many different animals, FREE, well kept, clean, pretty quiet also both times i was there.  The surrounding park area outside the zoo is expansive and beautiful and great for walking with your girlfriend/boyfriend or family.  Neat little shops in the surrounding area also in designated pathways.  Honestly, this "area" to include the surrounding area outside the park reminds me of Central Park in New York with it's massive size and beauty.  We walked past a small lake and rented a little boat for an hour.  Really, you can't go wrong with this.  Use the zoo as your destination for wandering around and then explore the surrounding area as well.  You'll hit it out of the park on this one!!!
Great free zoo. Beautiful shady zoo gardens with mostly modern habitats. Animals well cared for. Spent hours with school age kids.

We came towards the end of the day, and boy was it depressing. The zoo seems like it's on its way out. It was disappointing to find no lion and by the time we made it to the area with the tiger we weren't allowed to go in, despite the zoo not shutting for another 20mins. The enclosures didn't seem fantastic either. If you've got some spare time and are in the park, then it's maybe worth a visit. Otherwise you probably have a better zoo local to you in your own country.

A lovely park/garden full of beautiful plants, trees and sculptures. A peaceful place for a walk or just wondering around. If is your first time in CDMX, is a good place to see another side of the city. Also, a good news for the travelers is the park has free WiFi.

A marvelous park with squirrels everywhere. The perfect place to go exercise or do sports. The squirrels literally eat out of your hand. There are many signs explaining the workings of the park; for example, there are 'baby plant' fields everywhere - after they've grown a bit bigger - they're taken to the fields and are set up to grow larger into adult plants. They really dedicate a lot to the flora of the park. You can get fresh drinks here as well as there are some stables selling them inside the park.
The squirrels are awesome!

Nice park to take a ride or a walk with friends or just alone, kinda clean but be sure of not staying too late because this zone gets a little dangerous at night, you could get robbed or assaulted. No photos for the moment, hope this helped. It's like any other casual park, baseball courts, football soccer courts and gym equipment.

🌳 Such a beautiful and important park in the middle of the city, great place to walk around, jog, run, and appreciate nature. Entrance is free. 🚸 Lots of kid-friendly educational signs explaining the work that is done there and the importance of trees. ⚠ Beware of the squirrels, stand beside them for 5 seconds and they'll start climbing you! 😂

We came here as part of a smaller tour and it was nice experience with a lot of historical significance. Throughout our tour of Mexico City, there was always various references of the Spanish influence in the history
and development of the city. The site clearly depicts the three periods of Mexican history reflected in the architecture of the buildings. The plaza, designed my Mexican architect Mario Pani, was the sight of the Tlatelolco Massacre and is honored by a large memorial stone.

Unique place that shows part of the Aztec’s market, a Spanish Cathedral (that they used stone from the market to create), and then modern Mexico’s housing all around it.
There are not many signs to read, so perhaps do some research before to appreciate what you are looking at.
Beautiful historical value, there's a lot of history in this site. Best visited with a tour guide so you can learn the rich history behind it.

We took a tour here as part of a small group. There is a lot of sad history here. I always wanted to come here for myself to soak it all in. It's beautiful all around with the ruins, the cathedral, and the plaza.
very cool site showing 3 mexican eras. the pre-columbian, the conquest, and the modern era. definitely travel with a guide who will explain the history behind what you'll see.

Are you a lover of modern art of all mediums? Are you interested in Slovenian artists and the inspiration behind their works? If so, this museum is not to be missed. There are many interesting paintings, sculptures, video artworks, and other curiosities. If you are squeamish about you or your children seeing nudity, this gallery may not be your cup of tea. But if you are comfortable seeing a few naked body art works sprinkled in with the other art work, do stop by. The museum has a downstairs coffee bar/lounge and lecture hall for talks.  I really enjoyed the museum and its art works.

Half of the space is permanent exhibition and other half is actual and temporary, usually open three times a year for a few months; always interesting topic. 
Otherwise calm and chilly space, where time and thoughts run slower tempo.

I was left speechless. The exhibits are so beautifully pieced together that it is almost impossible to peel your eyes off them. You will need about an hour to go through the whole gallery, after which you can relax in the cafè bellow the gallery itself. The gallery also provides a student discount, so be sure to bring your students' card!

Beautiful bulging and interesting permanent collection. You will need 30 minutes-1 hour to see it all. The temporary exhibition space is big and well organised. The thicket costs only 5 euros: an extra reason to have this insight into modern Slovenia. Visit the coffee downstairs if you have a little time.
One of my favourite places in Ljubljana to have a nice cup of coffee or tea and stay close to modern art. Highly recommended.

Beautiful! The garden is splendid with peacocks everywhere. The art collection is good but depends on your taste in the matter. There's even a little coffee shop closed to the house. Not that cheap for foreigners and being able to take photos inside cost an extra. But overall a good value.

One of my favorite spots of the city, it is a must if you consider yourself as a fan of Diego and Frida. Beautiful garden with peacocks and xolos... Mexican dogs. At the end you will find an exhibition of handcraft of all around Mexico, really well selected pieces.
A sanctuary for peacocks and this mexican dog Xoloitzcuintli. They also have an amazing art collection of Frida Khalo and Diego Rivera
Dolores Olmedo is a great Museum to know Rivera and Kahlo's work and many more details about Dolores Olmedo and her life. Beautiful place.

What a delightful little compound...a beautiful setting of animals (peacock birds and black, hairless, buckterth dogs) combined with artwork and a cute little restaurant.  I can confirm the beer is both cold and delish...the food is solid good also. I learned quite a bit about Diego, Olmegas, and Frida.  Informative and a nice surprise.

An incredible display of music and dance. Though the whole production was incredible, I was impressed the most with the 15 minute continuous drum session. Amazing! It just kept going and going with not one of the drummers (25 I think) even showing a momentous hesitation.

It's a Ballet place where in you can watch live performances. We went there to see just the building and it's architecture. We loved it. It is easily accessible by public transportation. Infact, it is right outside Belle Arts Metro Station. While, you are there spend some time in the park right beside it. It is nice to cool off and rest.

A beautiful building, go see the Mexican folkloric ballet there.
This is a beautiful building from outside but the opera also nice from the inside. The Mexican folkloric ballet spectacle was just amazing. The music, costumes, it's a beautiful performance, definitely go and see it if you are in Mexico city for few days. We bought the cheapest tickets (around 15 euros) and we could see the stage well, you don't need to be worried about not seeing much of the show from the gallery. It's cheaper to buy the tickets directly at the Palacio de Bellas Artes ticket office than to buy them online on their website so worth going there in person to check for available spaces if you are in the city for few days.

Beautiful art deco style building featuring murals from some of Mexico's most well regarded artists. It's free to go in the first floor but you can only admire the architecture from there. To see the murals pay 75 pesos to go upstairs. I love how the revolutionary history of mexico is celebrated. Not a lot of English or particularly friendly but it's easy enough to get sorted and enjoy.

This is the gem of Mexico City! We returned to the area several times just to see it "one more time" in all its glory. Inside is Art Deco galore. The Diego Rivera (and other) murals are massive and definitely worth the trip, alone. The architecture floor features Mexico City's undertaking for the Olympics in the 1960's. It was fascinating to see the story unfold. Have coffee across the street at Sears to enjoy Bellas Artes and its visitors. The adjacent Alemda Park is a great place to relax.

This is the worst museum that I’ve ever visited. The exhibition is very limited. You only need 15 mins to finish everything. Except for lacking of works and exhibitions. The most disgusting thing to me is the lady who works at the lock room. I went to pick my backpack up. She was rolling her eyes to more than twice. She looked at my number and looked away. I said pickup again. She was moving slowly to get my backpack. I have no idea what does to her. But this service makes me very uncomfortable.

First time here and what a delightful experience. Architecturally talking the building is excellent. Clean lines with tons of different textures. On the other hand the work in there is quite appealing and relevant. Modern and contemporary art. One day of the week entry is free. Don't forget to check the restaurant upstairs because it is delicious!

FREE ON SUNDAYS! This Museum is located in a big, beautiful park (with a children’s play area), and there are many outdoor sculptures as well as incredible exhibitions inside. There are guided tours available during the week, and they’re closed on Mondays.
This place is cool when you aren't frying balls on acid.... but if that's a possibility, I wouldn't suggest against it.
It's one of those you just cannot miss. You'll love it.

Museum itself very nice but i will give 3 stars because there isnt any english explantation and if i visit history museum, i expect a route from century to century what happen in the country but after i visit history museum what i learn is nothing.
Beautiful castle, great views, but unfortunately the narrative is only in Spanish and there's no audio guide available
I recommend checking this place out for 2-3 hours. To get in they take your passport so just be forewarned.
Absolutely beautiful museum. Mainly people go to for the views of the city and the beautiful architecture of this historic mansion.
Great museum. Nice objects and great views of the city from its balconies. Unfortunately the boards are only in Spanish
Great place to visit for a family day, also good for children. A little bit dirty, the bathrooms lack hygiene.

It needs some maintenance. Some exhibits are forgotten, they don't have light or stuff like that.
Thought it's not expensive, most of it is great and interesting.
Staff members know what they are well prepared and really nice.
Excellent day out with the children... They hated the idea of going, but once the they did not want to leave! Great educational fun.
Excellent Science Muesum. Visit it. Very goid setting.  Do not miss the unique ecosphere. Self sustained life in a closed seled sphere made of glass with water, flora and fauna.

It's a great place for children to get excited about science! The day I went the planetarium was sold out so I can't comment on that. There were quite a bit of workshops throughout the museum. The building seems to be under renovation. The front ticket booth was closed off. I would have given it five stars but some exhibits were broken or out of order.

A gorgeous space to explore. The highlight is Diego Rivera’s History of Mexico mural in the stairwell, but the gardens are truly lovely. There was a line when I arrived about 30 minutes after it opened, but it moved quickly. Valid ID (driver’s license is fine) required for entrance.
This used to be an old bull fighting ring I was told. The place inside is beautiful. The murals were a great dipection of mexicos history according to Diego Rivera.
Amazing art exhibitions all around the year. Cultural and traditional exhibitions en its different spaces.
The bizarre part of this place is that you have your ID retained, until you go out. Here you'll find an incredible architecture and garden, chambers of Juarez and murals of Diego Rivera.

As you might heard, Palacio Nacional has a vast and interesting murals paired by Diego Rivera, which I’ll describe in a moment, but the National Palace, has a fascinating important history...

It turns out, that it used to be:

Moctezuma's "New Houses"	

The site and much of the building material of the current building is of what were called Moctezuma II's "New Houses". This palace functioned as the Aztec tlatoani's residence and performed a number of official functions as well. The building was divided into two sections and decorated with marble and painted stucco. The main façade contained the shield of the monarchy, an eagle with a snake in its claws. It has three patios surrounded by porticos, indoor sanitary facilities, fountains and gardens. The bedrooms had tapestries of cotton, feathers and rabbit fur painted in bright colors. The floors were of polished stucco and covered in animal furs and finely-woven mats. There were rooms for servants, administrative staff, and military guards, along with kitchens, pantries and storage rooms. The richness of the palace surprised Cortés, which he relayed in letters to Charles I of Spain.

Part of Diego Rivera's mural depicting Mexico's history in the main stairwell

Left panel of Rivera's History of Mexico mural in the main stairwell
A number of changes were made during the rule of Porfirio Díaz. The English-made clock on the parapet was moved to the tower of the Church of Santo Domingo. The façade was cemented over and etched to look like stone block. Cloth awnings were placed on the windows of the upper floors. On pedestals near the main door, statues of female forms were placed. Inside, the ambassador's room, the dining room, the kitchens, the lounge, the garages and the stables were all refurnished. This was done at a time when French style was popular in Mexico.

Between 1926 and 1929, the third floor was added during the term of President Plutarco Elías Calles by Alberto J. Pani, an engineer and then finance minister and designed by Augusto Petriccioli.[1][3] Merlons were placed on the towers and parapet and decorative caps were placed on all three doors. The Dolores Bell was placed in a niche flanked by atlantes above the balcony above the central door. The façade was covered with red tezontle stone and installed stone frames on the doors, windows, cornices, and parapets. In the interior, a grand staircase of marble was installed in the central patio (where Diego Rivera would later paint The History of Mexico mural) and constructed stairs to the internal revenue department and the offices of the General Treasury in the north wing. The old Chamber of Deputies, abandoned after a fire in 1872, was reconstructed and re-inaugurated as a museum to the centennial. A statue of Benito Juárez was placed in the north wing near his old quarters. This statue was made with bronze from the cannons of the Conservative Army during the Reform War and from French projectiles from the Battle of Puebla. This caused the Palace to lose its Baroque (and French) appearance and give it the appearance it has today.

Palace as presidential residence	

All the viceroys that ruled New Spain during the colonial period lived in this residence except for Antonio de Mendoza and Juan O’Donojú, the first and last viceroys. After independence, the palace was home to the two emperors who ruled Mexico during brief periods: Agustin de Iturbide and Maximilian I of Mexico. The first president to live in the building was also Mexico's first president, Guadalupe Victoria, and its last occupant in the 19th century was Manuel González, president from 1880 to 1884. After that, the presidential residence was Los Pinos, but the National Palace became the official residence once again with Andrés Manuel López Obrador, president since 2018. Famous people who stayed here include Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz, Mateo Alemán, Friar Servando de Mier (he also died here), Alexander von Humboldt and Simón Bolívar.

The interior garden of this place is superb. Go as early as possible and ideally during the week so there aren't a lot of people there. Grab a beer from the cafeteria and chill on one of the benches and enjoy the sounds of birds and the water fountain.

Definitely my favorite museum in Mexico City. Such a fantastic collection and a breathtaking library, it boasts. It’s not the largest but well-organized and showcased, which may remind you of the Frick Collection in New York. Every single staff is elegant and friendly. The pinnacle of this place would be its terrace coffee shop which comes with a gorgeous ambience.
60 to 65 pesos for coffee or tea! They also charge a fee to enter to the cafeteria. Other than outrageous prices it has a nice garden and the museum is beautiful
This museum always has a good expo. The building itself is beautiful and don’t forget to visit their small but cozy library.
One of the most famous and nice museums In the city, you can enjoy the collections that they hace here and some temporal expositions

Very busy on a Sunday (free for local residents). Outdoor information was good, interesting and well spaced. In the indoor museum there wasn't much English info though which took away from understanding some of the displays. Overall veto worth a visit still

Visit here to get just a small idea of what the Spanish conquerers destroyed - incredible to see what a civilization without iron or the wheel achieved... Be aware you aren't allowed to take water onto the site so have a drink beforehand... It will be taken from you at the entrance security - as always in Mexico they are very nice about it.

This place is large an expansive as it including the ruins and the museum all in one ticket. I recommend you come with enough time to visit everything since it is all so interesting. They keep the place very well maintained and everything is so well laid out to view. This location is so close to the Zocalo that I recommend all travelers to come visit.

Enjoyed a wonderful visit to the ruins and museum.  Well set out displays and informative descriptions.  Must see when in Mexico City. Plan to spend at least a hour or more looking and absorbing the past.

Only in the end of the visitation (at the Museum) you will find information about the whole site. The site is pretty broken and difficult for the visitors to grasp what's going on without guides or audio guides. To me,  the museum bit does a great job going through the local culture and peoples who used to live there in the past.  A must go.

The architecture of the building it is situated in is interesting, and there are some paintings by famous Romanian artists, but I expected to see more paintings, maybe some by internationally painters, which was not the case.
One of the remarkable buildings, represents an important era which defines the history of the city. Unfortunately it is in deplorable condition.
A place to visit for Art lovers. One of the best spot around the center. It’s a must to see!
Very nice.Fine building.Easy accessible
Romanian artists with rare paintings.it is a very good way to understand the Romanian art evolution. The guide is recommended.was well informed and pleasant.

Fabulous museum. 10 lei entry. Lockers available but you need a 0.50 lei coin. Wonderful information on the history of Romania, then there is a Roman section with all the amazing friezes from the Roman column of traian. The treasury with all the gold and jewels is amazing! National costumes on the way out and a gun exhibition on until the end of April. Last tickets at 4.15pm. Need around 1hour.

Small museum with great stuff. We enjoyed the temporary exhibit. We learned a lot about how Romania came to be in it's modern form. The jewelry and sparkly things were awesome. That was only part of the museum not in English.

A great way to spend the day, if you have the time. Several exhibits have fantastic paintings, sculptures and tapestries from all over Europe, with the Romanian historical exhibit displaying a large collection that I'm sure can not be found anywhere else.

I got a bit disappointed. It was not as big as I expected it to be. Surely there has been made a quite amount of effort and the treasure rooms were interesting. Hope that the next time there will be a bigger variety of exhibits.
Very impressed with the exhibits. Surprised there was no mention of the time around 1989. For 10 lei it's a great destination and the souvenir shop is reasonably priced.

A great space for art lovers, and a must-do in mexico city. The space is great for taking pictures within lovely and colorful architecture, as well as getting to learn more about one of Mexico’s art icons and the history of the neighborhood’s scene in mid-XX century. If you get hungry during your visit, rest assured that the in-house coffee and restaurant has your back.

Very interesting museum even for people less interested in art. 
3 tips: 
1. Purchase tickets in the Internet. Otherwise the line may be very long. 
2. Take the audioguide. Definitely worth the extra money. Otherwise you will miss all the anecdotes and details. 
3. Taking photos requires extra payment....in principle😁

This is the house where Frida lived most of her life. It is beautiful and charming. I loved seeing her studio, the bedroom, the courtyard and imagining what it was like when she lived there. I recommend you purchase your tickets online so you don’t have to wait in line. We made the mistake of not paying the additional fee to take photos inside so unfortunately I have no photos of the inside.

A must while in Mexico city. 
Highly recommend that you buy your tickets ahead of time. 
The staff is extremely friendly and are super organized! This museum is well run for the amount of people they get daily!

Very nice. It is best to get an online ticket in advance, otherwise there is a long waiting line. Although this was a very relaxed waiting when I was there, the museum even handed out umbrellas for sun protection...
The building itself is part of the experience!

This small museum located very close to a speedway and is a source of historical facts for those who'd like a quick but exhaustive reminders on Trotsky Life in a general worldwide context. 
Efforts have been clearly put to preserve the house and its amenities: great glance into Trotsky "private Life. The garden is well preserved and is the perfect place to enjoy a coffee.
For 40 pesos (entrance fee), this museum is worth a visit! Don't forget to have a look at the drawing exhibition!

Not a lot of stuff is explained or written in English so it was hard to understand what was displayed. The outdoor courtyard was nice, tranquil, and relaxing. I could have been ok skipping this place.

You have to pay extra if you want to take photos. Didn't see anyone enforcing that, but it is a strange rule.

Historical. Interesting. There is a new café inside for a quick bite while you sit in the courtyard. My kids love the courtyard too because it's calming and beautiful. The house is beautiful and the photography and stories in the museum draw you in. The entrance fee is minor but the experience is impactful.
Super lovely and interesting.  It was neat to see where Trotsky lived during exile.  Too bad about the ice pick.
The place itself is beautiful. If you are into communism it would be meaningful too. The little cafeteria has good coffee and the temporal exhibitions (usually photography) are worth seeing.

An incredible display of music and dance. Though the whole production was incredible, I was impressed the most with the 15 minute continuous drum session. Amazing! It just kept going and going with not one of the drummers (25 I think) even showing a momentous hesitation.

It's a Ballet place where in you can watch live performances. We went there to see just the building and it's architecture. We loved it. It is easily accessible by public transportation. Infact, it is right outside Belle Arts Metro Station. While, you are there spend some time in the park right beside it. It is nice to cool off and rest.

A beautiful building, go see the Mexican folkloric ballet there.
This is a beautiful building from outside but the opera also nice from the inside. The Mexican folkloric ballet spectacle was just amazing. The music, costumes, it's a beautiful performance, definitely go and see it if you are in Mexico city for few days. We bought the cheapest tickets (around 15 euros) and we could see the stage well, you don't need to be worried about not seeing much of the show from the gallery. It's cheaper to buy the tickets directly at the Palacio de Bellas Artes ticket office than to buy them online on their website so worth going there in person to check for available spaces if you are in the city for few days.

Beautiful art deco style building featuring murals from some of Mexico's most well regarded artists. It's free to go in the first floor but you can only admire the architecture from there. To see the murals pay 75 pesos to go upstairs. I love how the revolutionary history of mexico is celebrated. Not a lot of English or particularly friendly but it's easy enough to get sorted and enjoy.

Our favorite market in Mexico City (so far), with lots of options, a cafe, and plenty to do in the surrounding area. The library and park to the south make this market worth the trip from across the city. 
Standard tourist craft market but relaxing and plenty of options.

Very nice craft market. Highly recommended to go here even if you aren't buying anything. Come here for sure if you are looking to buy some souvenirs to bring back home. You can get by with limited spanish as well. The prices are reasonable as well.

Would recommend this for souvenirs (ceramics, wooden Mexican crafts and textiles. Also - little colourful Jenga!)
Great place to see where locals buy goods and other things. Lots of fresh meat for sale. Also fried Scorpion 🤯 crocodile tacos and much more

Very busy on a Sunday (free for local residents). Outdoor information was good, interesting and well spaced. In the indoor museum there wasn't much English info though which took away from understanding some of the displays. Overall veto worth a visit still

They keep the place very well maintained and everything is so well laid out to view. This location is so close to the Zocalo that I recommend all travelers to come visit.

Only in the end of the visitation (at the Museum) you will find information about the whole site. The site is pretty broken and difficult for the visitors to grasp what's going on without guides or audio guides. To me,  the museum bit does a great job going through the local culture and peoples who used to live there in the past.  A must go.

Amazing art exhibitions all around the year. Cultural and traditional exhibitions en its different spaces.
The bizarre part of this place is that you have your ID retained, until you go out. Here you'll find an incredible architecture and garden, chambers of Juarez and murals of Diego Rivera.

As you might heard, Palacio Nacional has a vast and interesting murals paired by Diego Rivera, which I’ll describe in a moment, but the National Palace, has a fascinating important history...

It turns out, that it used to be:

Moctezuma's "New Houses"	

The site and much of the building material of the current building is of what were called Moctezuma II's "New Houses". This palace functioned as the Aztec tlatoani's residence and performed a number of official functions as well. The building was divided into two sections and decorated with marble and painted stucco. The main façade contained the shield of the monarchy, an eagle with a snake in its claws. It has three patios surrounded by porticos, indoor sanitary facilities, fountains and gardens. The bedrooms had tapestries of cotton, feathers and rabbit fur painted in bright colors. The floors were of polished stucco and covered in animal furs and finely-woven mats. There were rooms for servants, administrative staff, and military guards, along with kitchens, pantries and storage rooms. The richness of the palace surprised Cortés, which he relayed in letters to Charles I of Spain.

Part of Diego Rivera's mural depicting Mexico's history in the main stairwell

Left panel of Rivera's History of Mexico mural in the main stairwell
A number of changes were made during the rule of Porfirio Díaz. The English-made clock on the parapet was moved to the tower of the Church of Santo Domingo. The façade was cemented over and etched to look like stone block. Cloth awnings were placed on the windows of the upper floors. On pedestals near the main door, statues of female forms were placed. Inside, the ambassador's room, the dining room, the kitchens, the lounge, the garages and the stables were all refurnished. This was done at a time when French style was popular in Mexico.

Between 1926 and 1929, the third floor was added during the term of President Plutarco Elías Calles by Alberto J. Pani, an engineer and then finance minister and designed by Augusto Petriccioli.[1][3] Merlons were placed on the towers and parapet and decorative caps were placed on all three doors. The Dolores Bell was placed in a niche flanked by atlantes above the balcony above the central door. The façade was covered with red tezontle stone and installed stone frames on the doors, windows, cornices, and parapets. In the interior, a grand staircase of marble was installed in the central patio (where Diego Rivera would later paint The History of Mexico mural) and constructed stairs to the internal revenue department and the offices of the General Treasury in the north wing. The old Chamber of Deputies, abandoned after a fire in 1872, was reconstructed and re-inaugurated as a museum to the centennial. A statue of Benito Juárez was placed in the north wing near his old quarters. This statue was made with bronze from the cannons of the Conservative Army during the Reform War and from French projectiles from the Battle of Puebla. This caused the Palace to lose its Baroque (and French) appearance and give it the appearance it has today.

Palace as presidential residence	

All the viceroys that ruled New Spain during the colonial period lived in this residence except for Antonio de Mendoza and Juan O’Donojú, the first and last viceroys. After independence, the palace was home to the two emperors who ruled Mexico during brief periods: Agustin de Iturbide and Maximilian I of Mexico. The first president to live in the building was also Mexico's first president, Guadalupe Victoria, and its last occupant in the 19th century was Manuel González, president from 1880 to 1884. After that, the presidential residence was Los Pinos, but the National Palace became the official residence once again with Andrés Manuel López Obrador, president since 2018. Famous people who stayed here include Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz, Mateo Alemán, Friar Servando de Mier (he also died here), Alexander von Humboldt and Simón Bolívar.

What a great jump off point for Exploring Mexico City for the 1st time. there is lots to do nearby, lots of long walks with museums, shopping, restaurants, bus tours.  It was crowded but seemed safe if you got an early. Very clean and surprisingly Quiet. For beer lovers, all of the beer was delicious and told I would highly recommend trying new ones including Bohemia Brown and Clara.

Nice large plaza with a lot of space to walk around and also relax. The square is surrounded by a nice cathedral and government buildings and there are a bunch of shops on the main street. You can shop at some famous stores or go down another street nearby to get the local street food and vendors.

It's a very interesting place, a must go 8f you visit Mexico DF, not only for the Church, which is very beautiful, the history around but also for the local people that makes life every day there. You can see locals performing local dancing and traditions. You can buy some local crafts and take different options of tours to know the city on the bus, or go to different touristic places no so far from there.

Great place to walk and admire old architecture. A beautiful palace and a church are just steps ahead of the plaza. Also many nice small shop are available to enjoy a cup of coffee some sweets or a beer while visiting this place which is a most

You should walk through the Zocalo just to see these magnificent old buildings.  Walk in the main Cathedral.  Ask someone the time they retire the HUGE flag before night fall.  You missed it but we're told their military does this with such dignity.
A nice place to go when exploring the old parts of Mexico City
This museum it's quite small and not so easy to spot it.

Un lugar muy bello y conservado. Acceso gratuito y puedes observar parte de la historia de la imprenta. Así como la escritura braile. También hay exposiciones temporales variopintas. La información de cada exposición es buena y el arreglo también es adecuado.
Mucha historia y tranquilo, con buena atención por parte del personal.
Bonita casa escondida( pongan un letrero mas visible) en la esquina de moneda y primo de verdad.

a very impressive structure, even more so when you take into account the history of it's construction and hundreds of years of operation. To think that another layer of civilization lies just beneath it's stones is humbling.  The entire area is very scenic, bustling, and photogenic.

in the cathedral until.certain part you can act as a tourist and take pictures and walk on by...but there is a sector in which you have to hear the mass and enjoy the religious spirit of that place like any other conventional church in the world..good memories from 2014
The cathedral is absolutely breathtaking. It is an active place of worship, so be mindful of those praying. But take lots of pictures.

Metropolitan cathedral is right at zocalo. The church was quite nice and the accoustics were very interesting. The prayers seem to boom in the church creating a very calm atmosphere. It is a quick visit and is open past 5 which means you can visit the cathedral after all the other things close down.

The cathedral is stunning and worth the visit. And can get really crowded between all the tourists escaping the sun and the actual services that are constantly taking place. Be sure to note how the building is leaning due to the fact it’s built on top of a pyramid.
Very beautiful architecture.
Absolutely fascinating, you should come here
Breathtaking, beautiful.
This church is a very nice tourist spot!
I was nice and love the atmosphere
It's such a beautiful church. The interiors are well preserved and taken care of meticulously. Such a contrast the peace inside and the chaos surrounding it.
DOV: 19Aug2014  Its a old Catholic church, with beautiful artistic carvings,  located in street Francisco Good place to have room around along with other nearby areas.
Wonderful gold plated images. A peaceful precinct to stop and find one's thoughts....
Quite beautiful.
Great!!
bello lugar con reminiscencias históricas...

Un templo maravilloso de arte barroco afuera y dentro del templo, hay muchísimos detalles que apreciar en su interior ya que los detalles de cada altar, así como del principal son fastuosos por lo que les aseguro que si son admiradores del arte barroco quedarán encantados con cada detalle de este edificio, vale la pena pasar a el cuando vean sus puertas abiertas
Preciosa parroquia por dentro y fuera, algo imperdible si visitas la #cdmx
Excelente para orar
Me encantó! Es una iglesia bellísima! Los retablos exquisitos en oro de hoja! El trabajo de ebanisteria elaborado hasta el más fino detalle! Ampliamente recomendable!

Such a beautiful palace needs to be known by everyone that comes to Mexico.
The Mexican medicine museum, a pretty complete library, the historical archive as well as the meetings hall and the exposition of the Inquisition and torture.
You can even find lots of cultural activities almost daily there.

Interesting exhibits on medicine in Mexico, including traditiinal indigenous medicine, medical art installations, and preserved turn of the century medical school rooms and laboratories. For someone who is in medicine this will be very fascinating, but others may not be as excited. Also, it's free!
I recommend the tour of the museum. There was a lot to see.
This is a medical history not, as I assumed, a focus on the Spanish Inquisition .

Formerly the headquarters of the Inquisition that later became the academy of medicine. It now serves as a museum to the history of medicine in Mexico, spanning pre-hispanic times to the 20th century. It's worth a visit just to see the building itself which is quite architecturally impressive and unique. Be sure to note the "hanging arches" in each of the four corners which don't rest on columns!

The building itself is worth the visit. One of the most majestic and important palaces in the Americas.
The exhibitions tend to be magnanimous, world renowned artists and the permanent collection is superb.
An obligated visit when traveling to Mexico City

Absolutely brilliant and worth every peso (70) for entrance. The building itself is outstanding and the works inside are among the best you'll see anywhere. Take at least a couple of hours or more to really appreciate everything. Highly recommended
By far the best museum in Mexico City! Forget the rest of the overrated museums, this has a rich history and beautiful architecture in the heart of Downtown. Definitely worth the trip!

Amazing collection of Mexican artists in a building full of history in the heart of CDMX.  It really worth a visit.  It is paid,  but it is inexpensive for those who love,  live and breathe art history.  The building is also a touristic attraction,  with its neoclassical and modernist features.
Some interesting things to see and beautiful inside.  Not too expensive so worth a walk through.

The interior garden of this place is superb. Go as early as possible and ideally during the week so there aren't a lot of people there. Grab a beer from the cafeteria and chill on one of the benches and enjoy the sounds of birds and the water fountain.

Definitely my favorite museum in Mexico City. Such a fantastic collection and a breathtaking library, it boasts. It’s not the largest but well-organized and showcased, which may remind you of the Frick Collection in New York. Every single staff is elegant and friendly. The pinnacle of this place would be its terrace coffee shop which comes with a gorgeous ambience.
60 to 65 pesos for coffee or tea! They also charge a fee to enter to the cafeteria. Other than outrageous prices it has a nice garden and the museum is beautiful
This museum always has a good expo. The building itself is beautiful and don’t forget to visit their small but cozy library.
One of the most famous and nice museums In the city, you can enjoy the collections that they hace here and some temporal expositions

Free, exhibit upstairs has cool statues. They need signage telling you where you can and can’t go. Everything seemed to be under construction. I recommend if you are in the area. You can keep your backpack on you until you get to the small exhibit upstairs.
Good exhibition

Emblemático edificio donde el arte no tiene límite. 
Actualmente está en restauración pero es factible visitar la galería.

Un espacio bellísimo. La arquitectura del lugar es deliciosa. Un completo deleite a la vista, el cual es acompañado por algunas réplicas de esculturas de relevancia artística. La sala de exposición permanente es hermosa, los tragaluz, columnas y techos pintados son perfectos; y se puede apreciar la acuñación de monedas y más esculturas y pinturas.
Exelente escuela
My favorite place!
Mostly intimate works in a small space. Some nice young ladies explained the various printing techniques and helped me design a bookmark.
Me gusto mucho. Fuimos en domingo y fue gratis.  Y además hay un taller, mi hija hizo un grabado hermoso.  Personal atento.

Brinda buena atención y las obras que puedes apreciar tanto permanentes como aquellas que son temporales están muy bien. Hay un lugar en donde dejar tus pertenencias para no cargarlas contigo durante la visita. También hay guías quienes se encargan de explicar o expandir tu conocimiento sobre el tema de tu interés.
Me encanta esta en una plaza muy bonita. Las exposiciones geniales. El personal con excelente trato. Y con la posibilidad de hacer una estampa en el taller.

It was kind of evening when I arrived over here !this place is full of history. You can go through the boards which are full of information. It consists of history from three different time period. It closes early around 5-6 so make sure to be here on time.

Some of the area is damaged during the earthquake so one can not visit but it is one of the most historical place in CMDX!
Ok

un gran vistazo a uno de los eventos más impactantes de nuestra historia, muestra testimonios, noticias que nos muestran todo lo que llevo al país a vivir un día tan oscuro como el 2 de octubre de 1968. Es bastante completo y conmovedor
Bastante entretenido por sus exposiciones temporales y muy buena la dispocisión y la cantidad de información que proporcionan.

Es de los mejores museos que he visto, tiene mucho dinero invertido y la experiencia fue maravillosa.
La historia de México y los estudiantes marcada aquí
If you want to stroll past humanity's footwear history, this is the place to go.
Great for a quick stop. And free!
Great collection of shoe examples throughout the centuries.
Un lugar interesante para visitar. Sólo tomará unos minutos
Muy interesante! Calzados para ver de todas las épocas. Entrada Gratuita.

Nice colonial building behind El Templo Mayor, ir has as expected archaeological remains in its basement with many ancient Aztec pieces exposed besides other expositions, a public library with adult and kid oriented material and a nice view in the upper terrace. Absolutely recommended!
Soundcheck at the rooftop. Ready for the jam session. 🤓
Nice place but crowded and difficult to arrive if not using taxi or Uber.
Beautiful window to prehispanic times.

I've been coming here for almost a decade now. Seems it's getting pricier but neither the food nor the service are worth it, specially the "patatas bravas" which was a 'must' of this place. Still, their cultural offering is amazing, always great events and placed behind Mexico City's Cathedral helps build the ambiance.
Saw a presentation on the classical Mexican movie period and it's biggest stars.  Liked it. Very professionally curated.

A great museum always with a great exibition! And the best, is for free, Wednesday to Monday, from 10h to 18h. Going there, don't miss the visit to the Cafe and bookstore and the roof top. Has a nice view. The only thing is, the roof top isn't wheelchair accessible. The rest of the museum is. Great place to go by yourself, with friends, family or the special one. If you are in Mexico City don't let to go there.
A pretty museum with easy (and free) admission.  Take a little time and enjoy!
It’s got a fun terrace and the one floor on ‘68 is very good. If you’re passing by do pop in.

I love this museum. They always have interesting exhibitions here. I try to visit every time I'm in the city. Currently running is a retrospective on humor in Mexican cinema. The rooftop cafe is also worth a visit.
Excellent place to many people to come around the world 🌎
Good place to take out your children and enjoy learning about science and natural phenomena, even if is a toddler. Perfect to spend time with your family.
Beautiful old building. Loved the museum.
Really cool variety of exhibits, all in Spanish. Highly recommend, good for families. Staff seems really eager to close, we got lights turned out on us 5-10 minutes before closing.
Very nice place for kids. Very kind guidance

An incredible display of music and dance. Though the whole production was incredible, I was impressed the most with the 15 minute continuous drum session. Amazing! It just kept going and going with not one of the drummers (25 I think) even showing a momentous hesitation.

It's a Ballet place where in you can watch live performances. We went there to see just the building and it's architecture. We loved it. It is easily accessible by public transportation. Infact, it is right outside Belle Arts Metro Station. While, you are there spend some time in the park right beside it. It is nice to cool off and rest.

A beautiful building, go see the Mexican folkloric ballet there.
This is a beautiful building from outside but the opera also nice from the inside. The Mexican folkloric ballet spectacle was just amazing. The music, costumes, it's a beautiful performance, definitely go and see it if you are in Mexico city for few days. We bought the cheapest tickets (around 15 euros) and we could see the stage well, you don't need to be worried about not seeing much of the show from the gallery. It's cheaper to buy the tickets directly at the Palacio de Bellas Artes ticket office than to buy them online on their website so worth going there in person to check for available spaces if you are in the city for few days.

Beautiful art deco style building featuring murals from some of Mexico's most well regarded artists. It's free to go in the first floor but you can only admire the architecture from there. To see the murals pay 75 pesos to go upstairs. I love how the revolutionary history of mexico is celebrated. Not a lot of English or particularly friendly but it's easy enough to get sorted and enjoy.

This is the gem of Mexico City! We returned to the area several times just to see it "one more time" in all its glory. Inside is Art Deco galore. The Diego Rivera (and other) murals are massive and definitely worth the trip, alone. The architecture floor features Mexico City's undertaking for the Olympics in the 1960's. It was fascinating to see the story unfold. Have coffee across the street at Sears to enjoy Bellas Artes and its visitors. The adjacent Alemda Park is a great place to relax.
Beautiful building, inside and outside! Worth seeing just that, has various exhibitions, some better than others.
This is an amazing postal museum. Go just admire the building, the elevator, the architectural design, for FREE!
Beautiful baroque architecture. Although there is a restricted access to most interiors its definitely worth seeing and admiring.

Uno de mis lugares favoritos en la ciudad, la fachada y el interior tienen detalles exquisitos a la vista. Para dar un recorrido por sus interiores y tener una explicación más detallada hay que estar al pendiente de su cartelera cultural.
El personal generalmente es amable aunque celoso al conservar el edificio.

Uno de los edificios más bellos e imponentes del centro histórico de la ciudad de México. Está abierto al público para visitar la zona de vestíbulo y sus escaleras que son impresionantes. National Bank of Mexico
Beautiful
Porque se dice banco pero no atiebden tus problemas.
Muy amables y sin filas para que me atendieran

What a fantastic off the beaten path museum this is! Every exhibit was thoughtfully curated. I enjoyed every minute here. We spent nearly two hours here, and the museum is not that big. Free admission and worth a visit if you like photography.
Great exhibit of the Photo Bienal
One of my favorites museums un Mexico City
Ok
Very nice free photography museum. Great descriptions and layout. I really enjoyed my visit, although it can be hard to find the door to get in at times .

Great option for taking your kids while in Mexico City and your wife is shopping for endless hours in La Ciudadela market. ;) Such a peaceful and wonderful place! Kids library got an interesting collection and the communal space and garden is perfect for seating down and quiet time. You wont regret it. My kids didn’t want to leave.

A beautiful relaxing building that’s free to walk around or sit with a drink. With the market nearby I don’t know why more people don’t visit this place to get out of the sun.

Get some juice or a soda and collapse on a bench with a good book. If you need a spot to plan out your stay/trip this could be it. Read about Mexico City or Trotsky or Frida. Or do that weird NYT thing where you look into your significant other’s eyes for 3 minutes.

WIFI WORKS!!!!!!!  There is a place with tables and chairs where the WIFI works pretty well. The downside, is that there are just few tables equiped with electricity sockets to plug in your computer or phone.

If you are a lover of libraries or interesting public spaces, add this to your itinerary when visiting Mexico City. It's just a short walk from La Ciudadela and Mercado de San Juan  and adds a nice diversity to the experience of the city. It is made up of several small libraries that house private collections each in uniquely designed spaces specifically for the owners of the collections. (I hope I got those details right!)
This is a wonderful library. Fantastic architecture,  quiet reading rooms,  lively children's section,  and fairly good bookshop. Worth a visit!

An amazing and beautiful market of local crafts and goods. A must visit if you want hand made gifts such as poterry or decorations for your home. 

You can find all sorts of things here from jewelry, magnets, hand painted pottery, wall hangings, decorative fabrics, to clothes.

I felt very safe walking around alone as a woman not knowing any Spanish. Most people don't know English but I was able to get by fine. Some places take cards but I recommend having cash on you.

Our favorite market in Mexico City (so far), with lots of options, a cafe, and plenty to do in the surrounding area. The library and park to the south make this market worth the trip from across the city.
